title: Chronic Limb Ischemia
diagnosis_topic: Peripheral artery disease causing rest pain and ulceration
setup_script: A 58-year-old man with diabetes, hyperlipidemia and a long smoking history presents with progressive right foot pain at rest and a non-healing ulcer on the great toe. He notes claudication symptoms for months now limiting his walking distance to one block.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 140/80 mmHg, HR 85 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37 C.
Diminished dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses on right, ankle-brachial index 0.4, ulcer with necrotic base at first toe.
Duplex ultrasound shows multilevel occlusive disease in superficial femoral and popliteal arteries; CT angiography demonstrates distal tibial runoff.
Start antiplatelet, statin, smoking cessation counseling and optimize diabetes.
Plan for infra-inguinal bypass or endovascular intervention.
Ulcer progresses to gangrene requiring amputation.
Debridement, off-loading and infection control are essential.
Rest pain and tissue loss are indications for revascularization.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident contemplates conservative vs. surgical
dynamic_flow.reply: Recognize that exercise therapy alone is insufficient given critical limb ischemia.
Long-term follow-up with ABI and duplex; manage risk factors aggressively.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about amputation level
dynamic_flow.reply: Determined by perfusion and tissue viability if revascularization fails.

critical_decision_points: Recognizing critical limb ischemia with rest pain and tissue loss
Initiation of risk factor modification and medical therapy
Appropriate diagnostic imaging to assess runoff
